posts.name: Judah
posts.cooked: Awesome, I‚Äôm currently trying to set up a vault server for my team. We currently use a shared drive.

posts.name: Bodi
posts.cooked:
The neat thing about Onshape is that it‚Äôs cloud based, so I can work on projects on any computer with access to internet and in some cases offline. You can also do group editing similar to google docs so that‚Äôs helpful since FRC thrives on collaboration. The biggest downside is it‚Äôs not the greatest for larger projects since it‚Äôs web based, so projects with 100+ pieces tend to be a bit laggy (depending on computer rendering capabilities and WiFi connectivity). We only started using it this off-season, but so far we‚Äôve been really happy with it.

(Edit) I‚Äôve never used anything other than onshape, so I have no idea how it compares to any other programs.
Solidworks

posts.name: Anthony Brogni
posts.cooked: My FRC team used Autodesk Fusion 360 for the ease-of-use and cloud collaboration. My Ri3D team at the U of M however uses SolidWorks. Both seem to be popular options and either one is an excellent choice.

posts.name: Diego
posts.cooked: I use onshape, it is pretty similar to Fusion. What i like about onshape though is that the software is all on the cloud, so if you don‚Äôt have a pretty good computer you are still able to use onshape.
